explanations.explanation: An alphabet is any finite, non-empty, set of characters or symbols
The greek symbol ∑ (sigma) is used to denote an alphabet

examples.title: The English Alphabet
examples.description: The 26 lowercase letters of the English alphabet

explanations.explanation: An alphabet is any finite, non-empty, set of characters or symbols
The greek symbol ∑ (sigma) is used to denote an alphabet

examples.title: The English Alphabet
examples.description: The 26 lowercase letters of the English alphabet

explanations.explanation: A string (also known as a word) from an alphabet Σ is a finite sequence of characters from Σ
A word is denoted as w. We write the string represented by w without quotation marks

examples.title: Binary Sequence
examples.description: a word over an alphabet ∑={0,1}

examples.title: English Word
examples.description: a word over the alphabet ∑={a,b,c,.......,x,y,z}

examples.title: DNA Codon
examples.description: a word over the alphabet ∑={A,C,G,T}

explanations.explanation: The empty string is a string containing no characters. It has equal standing with all other words in the language
The empty string is denoted as ε (greek epsilon)

examples.title: Example
examples.description: A word containing no characters

explanations.explanation: The length of a string w is the number of characters which are not equal to ε
The length of a string is denoted by |w|

examples.title: Example 1
examples.description: Because heεεεllo=hello

examples.title: Example 3
examples.description: Because εεεεεε=ε

explanations.explanation: A concatenation of two strings creates a new string
A concatenation of two strings w₁ and w₂ is denoted as w₁w₂

examples.title: Example 1
examples.example: If w₁=01 and w₂=110, then w₁w₂=01110

examples.title: Example 1
examples.example: If w₁=abc and w₂=defg, then w₁w₂=abcdefg

examples.title: Example 3
examples.example: If w₁=ACTT and w₂=εεεεεε, then w₁w₂=ACTT
examples.description: Concatenating a string with ε doesn't change the string

explanations.explanation: The string w₁ is a substing of w, if the whole of w₁ is contained inside w

examples.title: Example 1
examples.example: If w₁=abcd and w=abcdefgh, then w₁ is a substring of w

examples.title: Example 2
examples.example: If w₁=abcd and w=abcefgh, then w₁ is not a substring of w
examples.description: w₁ is not contained contiguously inside w

examples.title: Example 3
examples.example: If w₁=ε and w=abcefgh, then w₁ is a substring of w
examples.description: the empty string ε is a substring of all strings

explanations.explanation: The string w₁ is a suffix of w, if w₁ is a substring that appears at the end of w
Similarly, w₁ is a prefix of w₁ if it appears at the start of w

examples.title: Suffix
examples.example: If w₁=abcd and w=klmabcd, then w₁ is a suffix of w

examples.title: Prefix
examples.example: If w₁=abcd and w=abcdlmln, then w₁ is a prefix of w

examples.title: Prefix and Suffix
examples.example: If w₁=abcd and w=abcdabcd, then w₁ both a prefix and suffix w

examples.title: A String and Itself
examples.description: A string is both a substring, suffix, and prefix if itself

examples.title: The Empty String
examples.description: The empty string ε is both a substring, suffix, and prefix of any string

explanations.explanation: A language is a set of strings over an alphabet Σ. Languages can be finite or infinite.
Languages are usually denoted with set notation

examples.title: Binary Language
examples.example: The binary language L={0,1,01,10,11,.....} is the set of all strings over the alphabet Σ = {0,1}

examples.title: The Empty Language
examples.example: The empty language \(L=\phi\) contains no strings
examples.description: Notice that for \(  L_1 = \phi \quad \text{and} \quad L_2=\epsilon, \quad L_1 \ne L_2  \)

examples.title: Set Notation
examples.description: The language L is the set of all strings with an even length

explanations.explanation: The power of an alphabet \( \Sigma^k \), is the set of all strings of length k
The Kleene Star \( \Sigma^* \) is the set of all possible strings over an alphabet \( \Sigma \). Any language over \( \Sigma\) will be partial to \( \Sigma^* \)
The Language \( \L^+ \)is the set of all possible strings over  ∑ except \( \epsilon\) (i.e \( L^+=\Sigma^*\setminus{\epsilon} \)

examples.title: Example 1
examples.description: The set of all strings of length 2 from the binary alphabet

examples.title: Example 2
examples.description: There are 26³ sets of length 3 over the lowercase english alphabet

examples.title: Example 3
examples.description: \( \Sigma^*\) is the union of all possible languages of length 0 to infinity

examples.title: Example 4
examples.description: \( \Sigma^+\) is the union of all possible languages of length 1 to infinity
